facts.text: The appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court at Allahabad for a quo warranto against respondent 1, challenging his appointment as a Judge of that High Court.
Respondent 1 was enrolled as an advocate more than 20 years ago but was all along practising at Benaras and not in the High Court.
The writ petition came up for preliminary hearing before Broome and G. Kumar, JJ.
Broome, J. held that 'an advocate of a High Court' in Art. 217(2)(b) meant an advocate enrolled as such, irrespective of practice location.
G. Kumar, J. held that 'an advocate of a High Court' meant one who has practised for the required period in a High Court.
Matter referred to Mathur, J., who agreed with Broome, J., and the writ petition was dismissed on July 24, 1968.
High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether 'an advocate of a High Court' in Art. 217(2)(b) means an advocate enrolled as such irrespective of practice location, or one who has practised for at least ten years in a High Court.
Whether distinction in language between Art. 217(2)(b), Art. 124(3), and Art. 233(2) requires practice in High Court for judgeship qualification.

petitioner_arguments.text: Expression 'an advocate of a High Court' in Art. 217(2)(b) meant an advocate practising in the High Court and not one practising in courts subordinate to the High Court.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 217(2)(b); comparison with Art. 124(3) and Art. 233(2)

petitioner_arguments.text: Language in Art. 124(3)(a) and (b) distinguishes: 'a judge of a High Court' means one who worked in High Court, similarly 'an advocate of a High Court' means one who practised in High Court.
Art. 233(2) uses 'an advocate' simpliciter for district judge, distinguishing from 'advocate of a High Court' for High Court/Supreme Court judges requiring High Court practice.

respondent_arguments.text: On a plain reading, 'an advocate of a High Court' means an advocate enrolled as such, irrespective of whether he practised in the High Court or subordinate courts.

court_reasoning.text: Language of Art. 217(2)(b) is plain and means a person enrolled as an advocate of a High Court; if practice in High Court required, clause would explicitly say so.

Historical statutes like Legal Practitioners Act, 1879 (Ss. 3,4,41), Indian Bar Councils Act, 1926 (Ss. 8,9,10,14), Govt. of India Acts 1915 (S.101(3)(d)) and 1935 (S.220(3)(d)) use similar expressions meaning enrolled advocates entitled to practise in High Court or subordinates.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enrolment entitles practice anywhere subordinate or High Court.

court_reasoning.text: Accepting petitioner's view creates anomaly in Art. 124(3): Supreme Court advocate without High Court practice ineligible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Strange anomaly pointed out by Broome, J.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction with Art. 233(2) has no significance post Advocates Act, 1961 (S.16): only senior advocates and other advocates.

holdings.text: 'An advocate of a High Court' in Art. 217(2)(b) and Art. 124(3) means an advocate enrolled on the roll of a High Court, irrespective of practice location.
First contention of appellant fails; agrees with Broome and Mathur, JJ.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sengalani Gramani v. Subbayya Nadar Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: One of two decisions referred to by the Court

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Qualifications for appointment as Judge of High Court/Supreme Court/District Judge; interpretation of 'advocate of a High Court'

statutes_cited.name: Legal Practitioners Act, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition and rights of advocates enrolled in High Court to practise in High Court or subordinate courts

statutes_cited.name: Indian Bar Councils Act, 1926
statutes_cited.relevance: Roll of advocates of High Court; entitlement to practise; disciplinary jurisdiction

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1915
statutes_cited.relevance: Qualifications for High Court Judge: pleader of High Court for 10 years

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Qualifications for High Court Judge: pleader of High Court for 10 years, including succession and judicial office

statutes_cited.name: Advocates Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Classes of persons entitled to practise: senior advocates and other advocates; impacts distinction post-1961

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court agreed with Broome and Mathur, JJ. of the Allahabad High Court, holding that respondent 1 qualified under Art. 217(2)(b) as an enrolled advocate of over 10 years, irrespective of practice location. The appeal challenging the dismissal of the writ petition was dismissed.

key_quotes.text: The language used in Art. 217(2)(b) is plain and incapable of bearing an interpretation other than the one given by Broome, J., and agreeing with him by Mathur, J.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on plain meaning of the provision

key_quotes.text: One broad point against the interpretation sought by counsel for the appellant would be that the expression an advocate of a High Court in its ordinary plain meaning must mean a person who has by enrolling himself under the relevant provisions of law become an advocate of a High Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects requirement of High Court practice

key_quotes.text: If the meaning of the expression an advocate of a High Court as suggested on behalf of the appellant were to be accepted a very strange anomaly... would result while construing Art. 124(3).
key_quotes.speaker: court
